passages.text: EQUITY:INTERNET&NEWMEDIA
Cloud business gaining momentum on robust AI demand; maintain Buy

BABA announced that its quick commerce's (QC) daily average order volume reached 80mn in August, vs. our estimated 90mn for Meituan's (MT; 3690 HK, Buy). This is a temporary win for BABA given that its scale (in terms of order volume) used to be merely \(- 40\%\) of MT's. BABA has already seen some benefits from its QC investment. BABA views QC as a new growth driver in its own right, as well as a driver to the entire ecosystem. QC has contributed to solid \(25\%\) y- y growth of monthly active buyers on its flagship Taobao app in the first three weeks of August, according to BABA, which in turn lends support to the growth of its CMR (customer management revenue) and potential savings on the marketing dollars. As a result, BABA predicts its CMR to maintain a similar growth rate in the near term, as the \(10\%\) y- y growth registered in the June quarter. By FY2028E, QC will likely add additional an CNY1tn in GMV to BABA, according to management.

On the flip side, the QC investment, amounting to CNY11bn in the June quarter, dragged down the EBITA of China ecommerce group (CEG) by \(21\%\) y- y or CNY10bn. BABA indicated that the loss of CEG will likely peak in the September quarter, which we estimate likely hit CNY36bn, thus leading to a \(74\%\) y- y (by CNY33bn) drop in the EBITA of CEG. We believe CEG's profitability should be able to improve gradually from September, considering the significant upfront investment in building fulfillment capabilities and acquiring users through aggressive subsidies. Now that BABA's QC has reached such a sizeable scale, we believe it will start to shift emphasis from land grabs to optimizing efficiency. All of these may help deliver a \(41\%\) (q- q) narrowing of QC's loss to CNY21bn in the upcoming December.

In the long run, we think BABA's strength lies in the retail- related QC service, which is \(35\%\) of the QC market, while we believe MT's position in food- related QC remains strong backed by its entrenched users' mind share and strong grip on restaurant merchants. Yet, we believe BABA has big strength in retail- related QC. BABA can easily leverage its self- owned Freshippo supermarkets and many thousands of offline stores from brand partners on its ecommerce marketplace as suppliers for its QC.
(Continued on page 4. ..)
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates

Alibaba operates China's largest ecommerce platform (Taobao and Tmall). Alibaba is also the largest cloud service provider in China. Aside from ecommerce and cloud businesses, the company also provides digital media services (e.g. Youku), digital map service (Amap), among others.

We value Alibaba's China Ecommerce Group at USD199m based on 10x FY27F P/E; it is AliCloud business at USD111bn, based on 4x FY27F P/S; its international commerce business at USD12bn based on FYOF P/S of 0.5x. We value Alibaba's net valuation of non- core assets at USD39bn. The resulting TP is USD170. The benchmark index for this stock is Nasdaq Composite.

Downside risks include: margin downside due to ramp- up in investments; regulatory risks related to the payment and internet finance industry, which could hurt Alibaba's main business and its value in Ant Group.

Alibaba's business is environment- friendly as it does not cause pollution or generate greenhouse gas directly. Its ecommerce business may indirectly lead to an increase in paper waste from packaging materials used for parcels. Alibaba maintains good corporate governance practices, including easy access for investors and proper disclosures.
(...continued from front page 1)
Additionally, we note, it is the only ecommerce platform with both the seasoned expertise and nationwide delivery network necessary to provide this type of service.

AliCloud delivered solid \(26\%\) y- y revenue growth, better than the Street- expected \(20\%\) y- y, driven by strong Al- related demand. Al- related revenue accounted for over \(20\%\) of AliCloud's revenue from its external customers. Its capex during the quarter rose \(57\%\) q- q /2.2x y- y to CNY38.7bn, demonstrating BABA's confidence over the outlook for Al demand. BABA believes that its cloud revenue will likely continue to accelerate.

We cut FY26F/27F EBITA by \(22\% /11\%\) to factor in a higher QC investment for the rest of the year. Yet, as discussed above, we think the loss of QC may peak in the September quarter before narrowing sequentially from the upcoming December quarter, driven by trimmed investment and an enhanced monetization rate. Nomura forecasts the EBITA of CEG to drop by \(40\%\) in FY26F, before rebounding \(49\%\) next year. The consolidated EBITA will likely fare better - most of BABA's other business segments will likely continue to register improving bottom lines. As such, we project consolidated EBITA to drop \(33\%\) this fiscal year (FY26F) before rebounding strongly by \(57\%\) in FY27F.

We reaffirm Buy and raise our SOTP- based TP to USD170 from USD152, implying 16.5x FY27F (CY26F) P/E, vs. previously 14x CY26F P/E on the back of a stronger outlook for BABA's ecommerce and cloud businesses. The stock currently trades at 13.1x FY27F P/E.

Alibaba Group Holding (BABA US)

Valuation Methodology We value Alibaba's China Ecommerce Group at USD199bn, based on 10x FY27F P/E; it is AliCloud business at USD111bn, based on 4x FY27F P/S; its international commerce business at USD12bn, based on FY27F P/S of 0.5x. We value Alibaba's net valuation of non- core assets at USD39bn. The resulting TP is USD170. The benchmark index for this stock is Nasdaq Composite.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Downside risks include: margin downside due to ramp- up in investments; regulatory risks related to the payment and internet finance industry, which could hurt Alibaba's main business and its value in Ant Group.

A rating of 'Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Neutral', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to perform in line with the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Reduced', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Suspended', indicates that the rating, target price and estimates have been suspended temporarily to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies. Securities and/or companies that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'No rating' are not in regular research coverage. Investors should not expect continuing or additional information from Nomura relating to such securities and/or companies. Benchmarks are as follows: United States/Europe/Asia ex- Japan: please see valuation methodologies for explanations of relevant benchmarks for stocks, which can be accessed at: http://go.nomuranow.com/research/mDisclosures; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia, unless otherwise stated in the valuation methodology; Japan: Russell/Nomura Large Cap.

A 'Bullish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to outperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Neutral' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to perform in line with the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Bearish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to underperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. Sectors that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'N/A' are not assigned ratings. Benchmarks are as follows: United States: S&P 500; Europe: Dow Jones STOXX 600; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia. Japan/Asia ex- Japan: Sector ratings are not assigned.

A Target Price, if discussed, indicates the analyst's forecast for the share price with a 12- month time horizon, reflecting in part the analyst's estimates for the company's earnings. The achievement of any target price may be impeded by general market and macroeconomic trends, and by other risks related to the company or the market, and may not occur if the company's earnings differ from estimates.
